title: Visa Inc.
content:
{{short description|American multinational financial services corporation}} {{Redirect|VISA|the document needed to enter a country's territory|Travel visa||Visa (disambiguation)}} {{Use American English|date=February 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Visa Inc. | logo = Visa 2021.svg | image = Old Visa Inc headquarters.jpg | image_size = 250px | image_caption = Former headquarters at Metro Center in Foster City, California | type = [[Public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{ubl|{{NYSE|V}} (Class A)|[[DJIA]] component|[[S&P 100]] component|[[S&P 500]] component}} | founder = [[Dee Hock]] | industry = [[Financial services]] | foundation = {{Start date and age|1958|9|18}} (as BankAmericard in [[Fresno, California]], U.S.) | hq_location = [[One Market Plaza]], [[San Francisco, California]], U.S.{{cite web |url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/Visa-to-vastly-expand-SF-headquarters-with-move-14814671.php |title=Visa to vastly expand SF headquarters with move to Giants waterfront project |date=6 November 2019 |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |first=Roland |last=Li}} | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = {{unbulleted list|[[Alfred F. Kelly Jr.]] (chairman)|[[Ryan McInerney]] ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]]){{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/payments-giant-visa-names-new-ceo-2022-11-17/ |title=Visa promotes McInerney to CEO as Kelly moves to board |date=17 November 2022 |last=Saini |first=Manya |publisher=Reuters}}}} | products = {{ubl|[[Credit card]]s{{Citation needed|date=September 2022|reason=Visa does not issue credit cards}}|[[Payment system]]s}} | revenue = {{Increase}} {{USD|29.31 billion|link=yes}} (2022) | operating_income = {{Increase}} {{USD|18.81 billion}} (2022) | net_income = {{Increase}} {{USD|14.96 billion}} (2022) | assets = {{Increase}} {{USD|85.50 billion}} (2022) | equity = {{Decrease}} {{USD|35.58 billion}} (2022) | num_employees = {{circa|26,500}} (2022) | homepage = {{URL|https://visa.com}} | footnotes = Financials {{as of|2022|09|30|df=US|lc=y}}.
References:{{cite web |url= https://www.sec.gov/ix?doc=/Archives/edgar/data/0001403161/000140316122000081/v-20220930.htm |title=U.S. SEC: Visa Inc. Form 10-K |date=16 November 2022 |publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]}} }} '''Visa Inc.''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|v|iː|z|ə|,_|ˈ|v|iː|s|ə}}; stylized as '''''VISA''''') is an American [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] [[financial services]] corporation headquartered in [[San Francisco, California]].{{cite web|title=Visa Inc. 2021 Annual Report |url=https://s29.q4cdn.com/385744025/files/doc_downloads/Visa-Inc_-Fiscal-2021-Annual-Report.pdf |access-date=17 August 2022 |publisher=Visa Inc.}} It facilitates [[electronic funds transfer]]s throughout the world, most commonly through Visa-branded [[credit card]]s, [[debit card]]s and [[Stored-value card|prepaid card]]s.[http://www.corporate.visa.com Visa] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090930192322/http://corporate.visa.com/ |date=September 30, 2009 }}. Retrieved March 26, 2010. Visa is one of the [[List of public corporations by market capitalization|world's most valuable companies]]. Visa does not issue cards, extend credit or set rates and fees for consumers; rather, Visa provides financial institutions with Visa-branded payment products that they then use to offer credit, debit, prepaid and cash access programs to their customers. In 2015, the Nilson Report, a publication that tracks the credit card industry, found that Visa's global network (known as '''VisaNet''') processed 100 billion transactions during 2014 with a total volume of US$6.8 trillion.{{Cite web| url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/danielfisher/2015/05/06/visa-moves-at-the-speed-of-money/#12a2f9a61b99 | title=Visa Moves at the Speed of Money |last=Fisher| first=Daniel| website=Forbes| access-date=2016-05-01|date=2015-05-25}} This article is authored by a ''Forbes'' staff member. Visa was founded in 1958 by [[Bank of America]] (BofA) as the '''BankAmericard''' credit card program.{{cite book |last1=Stearns |first1=David L. |title=Electronic Value Exchange: Origins of the Visa Electronic Payment System |date=2011 |publisher=Springer |location=London |isbn=978-1-84996-138-7 |page=1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k2tTTBOImXMC&pg=PA1}} Available through SpringerLink. In response to competitor Master Charge (now [[Mastercard]]), BofA began to license the BankAmericard program to other financial institutions in 1966. By 1970, BofA gave up direct control of the BankAmericard program, forming a [[cooperative]] with the other various BankAmericard issuer banks to take over its management. It was then renamed Visa in 1976. Nearly all Visa transactions worldwide are processed through the company's directly operated VisaNet at one of four secure [[data center]]s, located in [[Ashburn, Virginia]]; [[Highlands Ranch, Colorado]]; [[London|London, England]]; and [[Singapore]].{{Cite web| url=https://baxtel.com/data-centers/visanet| title=Map and List of VisaNet's Data Centers| website=Baxtel}} These facilities are heavily secured against natural disasters, crime, and terrorism; can operate independently of each other and from external utilities if necessary; and can handle up to 30,000 simultaneous transactions and up to 100 billion computations every second.{{Cite web| url=http://www.networkcomputing.com/networking/inside-visas-data-center/1599285558|title=Inside Visa's Data Center {{!}} Network Computing |website=www.networkcomputing.com|access-date=2016-05-01|date=May 29, 2013 |last=Kontzer|first=Tony}}{{cite news| last1=Swartz| first1=Jon| title=Top secret Visa data center banks on security, even has moat| url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/tech/news/story/2012-03-25/visa-data-center/53774904/1 |access-date=20 February 2017|work=USA Today|date=25 March 2012}} Visa is the world's second-largest card payment organization (debit and credit cards combined), after being surpassed by [[China UnionPay]] in 2015, based on annual value of card payments transacted and number of issued cards.{{cite news|title=UnionPay takes top spot from Visa in $22 trillion global cards market – RBR|url=https://www.finextra.com/pressarticle/65412/unionpay-takes-top-spot-from-visa-in-22-trillion-global-cards-market---rbr|work=Finextra|publisher=Finextra Research Limited|location=London|date=22 July 2016}} However, because UnionPay's size is based primarily on the size of its domestic market in [[China]], Visa is still considered the dominant bankcard company in the rest of the world, where it commands a 50% market share of total card payments. ==History== [[File:Old Bankamericard sign.jpg|thumb|Old "Your BankAmericard Welcome Here" sign]] [[Image:Visad.jpg|thumb|A 1976 ad promoting the change of name to "Visa". Note the early Visa card shown in the ad, as well as the image of the BankAmericard that it replaced.]] On September 18, 1958, [[Bank of America]] (BofA) officially launched its '''BankAmericard''' credit card program in [[Fresno, California]]. In the weeks leading up to the launch of BankAmericard, BofA had saturated Fresno mailboxes with an initial mass mailing (or "drop", as they came to be called) of 65,000 unsolicited credit cards.{{cite web| title=History of Visa| url=http://usa.visa.com/about-visa/our-business/history-of-visa.jsp| access-date=March 19, 2013| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141003235354/http://usa.visa.com/about-visa/our-business/history-of-visa.jsp| archive-date=October 3, 2014| url-status=dead}} BankAmericard was the brainchild of BofA's in-house product development [[think tank]], the Customer Services Research Group, and its leader, [[Joseph P. Williams]]. Williams convinced senior BofA executives in 1956 to let him pursue what became the world's first successful mass mailing of unsolicited credit cards (actual working cards, not mere applications) to a large population.{{cite book |last1=Nocera |first1=Joseph |title=A Piece of the Action: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class |date=1994 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |isbn=9781476744896 |page=23 |edition=2013 paperback |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mZ5FAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA23}} Williams' pioneering accomplishment was that he brought about the successful implementation of the all-purpose credit card (in the sense that his project was not canceled outright), not in coming up with the idea. By the mid-1950s, the typical middle-class American already maintained [[revolving credit]] accounts with several different merchants, which was clearly inefficient and inconvenient due to the need to carry so many cards and pay so many separate bills each month.{{cite book |last1=Nocera |first1=Joseph |title=A Piece of the Action: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class |date=1994 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |isbn=9781476744896 |page=24 |edition=2013 paperback |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mZ5FAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA24}} The need for a unified financial instrument was already evident to the American financial services industry, but no one could figure out how to do it. There were already [[charge card]]s like [[Diners Club]] (which had to be paid in full at the end of each billing cycle), and "by the mid-1950s, there had been at least a dozen attempts to create an all-purpose credit card." However, these prior attempts had been carried out by small banks which lacked the resources to make them work. Williams and his team studied these failures carefully and believed they could avoid replicating those banks' mistakes; they also studied existing revolving credit operations at [[Sears]] and [[Mobil Oil]] to learn why they were successful. Fresno was selected for its population of 250,000 (big enough to make a credit card work, small enough to control initial startup cost), BofA's market share of that population (45%), and relative isolation, to control public relations damage in case the project failed.{{cite book |last1=Nocera |first1=Joseph |title=A Piece of the Action: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class |date=1994 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |isbn=9781476744896 |page=25 |edition=2013 paperback |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mZ5FAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA25}} According to Williams, [[Florsheim Shoes]] was the first major retail chain which agreed to accept BankAmericard at its stores.{{cite book |last1=Nocera |first1=Joseph |title=A Piece of the Action: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class |date=1994 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |isbn=9781476744896 |page=28 |edition=2013 paperback |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mZ5FAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA28}} {{multiple image |direction = vertical |align = left |width = 175 |image1 = Old Visa Logo.svg |alt1 = Visa logo from July 1, 1992 to 2000 |caption1 = Visa logo used from July 1, 1992 to 2000 |image2 = Former Visa (company) logo.svg |alt2 = Visa logo from August 1998 to 2006 |caption2 = Visa logo used from August 1998 to 2005 |image3 = Visa Inc. logo.svg |alt3 = Visa logo from late 2005 to May 2015 |caption3 = Visa logo used from late 2005 to January 2014 |image4 = Visa 2014 logo detail.svg |alt4 = Visa logo from January 2014 to July 2021 |caption4 = Visa logo used from January 2014 to July 2021 |image5 = Visa 2021.svg |alt5 = Visa logo since July 2021 |caption5 = Visa logo used since July 2021 |image6 = Visa.svg |alt6 = Visa acceptance logo used since early 2015 |caption6 = Visa acceptance logo from early 2015 (used only in certain Asian, American and European markets) }} The 1958 test at first went smoothly, but then BofA panicked when it confirmed rumors that another bank was about to initiate its own drop in San Francisco, BofA's home market.{{cite book |last1=Nocera |first1=Joseph |title=A Piece of the Action: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class |date=1994 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |isbn=9781476744896 |page=29 |edition=2013 paperback |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mZ5FAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA29}} By March 1959, drops began in San Francisco and [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]]; by June, BofA was dropping cards in [[Los Angeles]]; by October, the entire state of [[California]] had been saturated with over 2 million credit cards and BankAmericard was being accepted by 20,000 merchants. However, the program was riddled with problems, as Williams (who had never worked in a bank's loan department) had been too earnest and trusting in his belief in the basic goodness of the bank's customers, and he resigned in December 1959. Twenty-two percent of accounts were delinquent, not the 4% expected, and police departments around the state were confronted by numerous incidents of the brand new crime of [[credit card fraud]].{{cite book |last1=Nocera |first1=Joseph |title=A Piece of the Action: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class |date=1994 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |isbn=9781476744896 |page=30 |edition=2013 paperback |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mZ5FAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA30}} Both politicians and journalists joined the general uproar against Bank of America and its newfangled credit card, especially when it was pointed out that the cardholder agreement held customers liable for all charges, even those resulting from fraud.{{cite book |last1=Nocera |first1=Joseph |title=A Piece of the Action: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class |date=1994 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |isbn=9781476744896 |page=31 |edition=2013 paperback |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mZ5FAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA31}} BofA officially lost over $8.8 million on the launch of BankAmericard, but when the full cost of advertising and overhead was included, the bank's actual loss was probably around $20 million. However, after Williams and some of his closest associates left, BofA management realized that BankAmericard was salvageable.{{cite book |last1=Nocera |first1=Joseph |title=A Piece of the Action: How the Middle Class Joined the Money Class |date=1994 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |location=New York |isbn=9781476744896 |page=32 |edition=2013 paperback |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mZ5FAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA32}} They conducted a "massive effort" to clean up after Williams, imposed proper financial controls, published an open letter to 3 million households across the state apologizing for the credit card fraud and other issues their card raised and eventually were able to make the new financial instrument work. By May 1961, the BankAmericard program became profitable for the first time.{{cite book |last1=Stearns |first1=David L. |title=Electronic Value Exchange: Origins of the Visa Electronic Payment System |date=2011 |publisher=Springer |location=London |isbn=978-1-84996-138-7 |page=24|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k2tTTBOImXMC&pg=PA24}} Available through SpringerLink. At the time, BofA deliberately kept this information secret and allowed then-widespread negative impressions to linger in order to ward off competition.{{cite book |last1=Stearns |first1=David L. |title=Electronic Value Exchange: Origins of the Visa Electronic Payment System |date=2011 |publisher=Springer |location=London |isbn=978-1-84996-138-7 |page=25|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k2tTTBOImXMC&pg=PA25}} Available through SpringerLink. This strategy worked until 1966, when BankAmericard's profitability had become far too big to hide. The original goal of BofA was to offer the BankAmericard product across California, but in 1966, BofA began to sign licensing agreements with a group of banks outside of California, in response to a new competitor, Master Charge (now [[MasterCard]]), which had been created by an alliance of several regional bankcard associations to compete against BankAmericard. BofA itself (like all other U.S. banks at the time) could not expand directly into other states due to federal restrictions [[Riegle-Neal Interstate Banking and Branching Efficiency Act of 1994|not repealed until 1994]]. Over the following 11 years, various banks licensed the card system from Bank of America, thus forming a network of banks backing the BankAmericard system across the United States.[http://www.visalatam.com/e_aboutvisa/acerca_historia.jsp "History of Visa"], Visa Latin America & Caribbean. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071103060809/http://www.visalatam.com/e_aboutvisa/acerca_historia.jsp |date=November 3, 2007 }} The "drops" of unsolicited credit cards continued unabated, thanks to BofA and its licensees and competitors until they were outlawed in 1970,The Unsolicited Credit Card Act of 1970 amended the [[Truth in Lending Act]] of 1968 to ban the mailing of unsolicited credit cards. It is now codified at 15 U.S.C. § 1642. but not before over 100 million credit cards had been distributed into the American population.Nocera, 15. During the late 1960s, BofA also licensed the BankAmericard program to banks in several other countries, which began issuing cards with localized brand names. For example:{{citation needed|date=November 2010}} * In Canada, an alliance of banks (including [[Toronto-Dominion Bank]], [[Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce]], [[Royal Bank of Canada]], [[Banque Canadienne Nationale]] and [[Scotiabank|Bank of Nova Scotia]]) issued credit cards under the ''Chargex'' name from 1968 to 1977. * In France, it was known as ''[[Carte Bleue]]'' (Blue Card). The logo still appears on many French-issued Visa cards today. * In Japan, [[The Sumitomo Bank]] issued BankAmericards through the Sumitomo Credit Service. * In the UK, the only BankAmericard issuer for some years was [[Barclaycard]]. The branding still exists today, but is used not only on Visa cards issued by [[Barclays]], but on its MasterCard and [[American Express]] cards as well.{{cite web|url=http://www.barclaycard.co.uk/personal/customer/cashback/guide |title=Welcome to Barclaycard Cashback | Barclaycard |access-date=2014-08-23 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826114414/http://www.barclaycard.co.uk/personal/customer/cashback/guide |archive-date=August 26, 2014 }} * In Spain until 1979 the only issuer was [[Banco de Bilbao]]. In 1968, a manager at the National Bank of Commerce (later [[Rainier Bancorp]]), [[Dee Hock]], was asked to supervise that bank's launch of its own licensed version of BankAmericard in the [[Pacific Northwest]] market. Although Bank of America had cultivated the public image that BankAmericard's troubled startup issues were now safely in the past, Hock realized that the BankAmericard licensee program itself was in terrible disarray because it had developed and grown very rapidly in an ''ad hoc'' fashion. For example, "interchange" transaction issues ''between'' banks were becoming a very serious problem, which had not been seen before when Bank of America was the sole issuer of BankAmericards. Hock suggested to other licensees that they form a committee to investigate and analyze the various problems with the licensee program; they promptly made him the chair of that committee.Nocera, 89-92. After lengthy negotiations, the committee led by Hock was able to persuade Bank of America that a bright future lay ahead for BankAmericard — outside Bank of America. In June 1970, Bank of America gave up control of the BankAmericard program. The various BankAmericard issuer banks took control of the program, creating National BankAmericard Inc. (NBI), an independent [[Delaware General Corporation Law|Delaware corporation]] which would be in charge of managing, promoting and developing the BankAmericard system within the United States. In other words, BankAmericard was transformed from a franchising system into a jointly controlled consortium or alliance, like its competitor Master Charge. Hock became NBI's first president and CEO.Nocera, 90-93. However, Bank of America retained the right to directly license BankAmericard to banks outside the United States and continued to issue and support such licenses. By 1972, licenses had been granted in 15 countries. The international licensees soon encountered a variety of problems with their licensing programs, and they hired Hock as a consultant to help them restructure their relationship with BofA as he had done for the domestic licensees. As a result, in 1974, the International Bankcard Company (IBANCO), a multinational member corporation, was founded in order to manage the international BankAmericard program.{{citation |last1=Batiz-Lazo |first1=Bernardo |last2=del Angel |first2=Gustavo |title=The Dawn of the Plastic Jungle: The Introduction of the Credit Card in Europe and North America, 1950-1975 |journal=Economics Working Papers |publisher=Hoover Institution |date=2016 |page=18 |url= https://ideas.repec.org/p/hoo/wpaper/16107.html}} {{multiple image | align = right | image1 = Barclaycard.png | width1 = 150 | alt1 = | caption1 = | image2 = Chargex.svg | width2 = 150 | alt2 = | caption2 = | footer = Sample [[Barclaycard]] (left), as issued in the UK in the 1960s/70s. Co-branded cards were also issued by affiliates, such as [[The Co-operative Bank]] and [[Yorkshire Bank]]. The Chargex logo (right) used in Canada. }} In 1976, the directors of IBANCO determined that bringing the various international networks together into a single network with a single name internationally would be in the best interests of the corporation; however, in many countries, there was still great reluctance to issue a card associated with Bank of America, even though the association was entirely nominal in nature. For this reason, in 1976, BankAmericard, Barclaycard, Carte Bleue, Chargex, Sumitomo Card, and all other licensees united under the new name, "'''Visa'''", which retained the distinctive blue, white and gold flag. NBI became Visa USA and IBANCO became Visa International.{{Cite book|title=Technological Innovation in Retail Finance: International Historical Perspectives|last=Thomes|first=Paul|publisher=Routledge|year=2011|isbn=978-0-203-83942-3|location=New York|pages=256}} The term ''Visa'' was conceived by the company's founder, Dee Hock. He believed that the word was instantly recognizable in many languages in many countries and that it also denoted universal acceptance.{{cite news|title=VISA|newspaper=The Good Schools Guide |date=February 8, 2017 |url=https://www.goodschoolsguide.co.uk/degree-apprenticeships/employers/700033-1.html|publisher=TheGoodSchoolsGuide|access-date=August 30, 2019}} The announcement of the transition came on December 16, 1976, with VISA cards to replace expiring BankAmericard cards starting on March 1, 1977 (initially with both the BankAmericard name and the VISA name on the same card), and the various Bank of America issued cards worldwide being phased out by the end of October 1979. "BankAmericard to become Visa", ''The Courier-Journal'' (Louisville KY), December 16, 1976, p. B 10 In October 2007, Bank of America announced it was resurrecting the BankAmericard brand name as the "BankAmericard Rewards Visa".[http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2007/10/15/daily17.html "BofA resurrects Bankamericard brand"], San Francisco Business Times. Following the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]], in March 2022, Visa announced that it would suspend all business operations in [[Russia]].{{cite web|title=Mastercard and Visa suspend operations in Russia|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/05/world/europe/mastercard-visa-suspend-operations-russia.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|last=Paybarah|first=Azi|date=March 5, 2022|access-date=March 6, 2022}} ===Corporate structure=== Prior to October 3, 2007, Visa comprised four non-stock, separately incorporated companies that employed 6,000 people worldwide: the worldwide parent entity Visa International Service Association (Visa), Visa USA Inc., Visa Canada Association, and Visa Europe Ltd. The latter three separately incorporated regions had the status of group members of Visa International Service Association.{{Citation needed|date=November 2021}} The unincorporated regions Visa Latin America ([[Latin America and the Caribbean|LAC]]), Visa Asia Pacific and Visa Central and Eastern Europe, Middle East and Africa (CEMEA) were divisions within Visa.{{Citation needed|date=November 2021}} ===Billing and finance charge methods=== Initially, signed copies of sales drafts were included in each customer's monthly billing statement for verification purposes—an industry practice known as "country club billing"{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}}. By the late 1970s, however, billing statements no longer contained these enclosures, but rather a summary statement showing posting date, purchase date, reference number, merchant name, and the dollar amount of each purchase.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} At the same time, many issuers, particularly Bank of America, were in the process of changing their methods of finance charge calculation. Initially, a "previous balance" method was used—calculation of finance charge on the unpaid balance shown on the prior month's statement. Later, it was decided to use "average daily balance" which resulted in increased revenue for the issuers by calculating the number of days each purchase was included on the prior month's statement. Several years later, "new average daily balance"—in which transactions from previous and current billing cycles were used in the calculation—was introduced. By the early 1980s, many issuers introduced the concept of the annual fee as yet another revenue enhancer.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} ===IPO and restructuring=== On October 11, 2006, Visa announced that some of its businesses would be merged and become a [[publicly traded company]], Visa Inc.[http://www.corporate.visa.com/visainc/index.html?=corp Visa, Inc. Corporate Site] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204073906/http://www.corporate.visa.com/visainc/index.html?=corp |date=February 4, 2007 }}.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6043406.stm "Visa plans stock market flotation"], ''BBC News – Business'', October 12, 2006.Bawden, Tom. [http://business.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,9063-2399908,00.html "Visa plans to split into two and float units for $13bn."], ''The Times'', October 12, 2006. Under the IPO restructuring, Visa Canada, Visa International, and Visa USA were merged into the new public company. Visa's Western Europe operation became a separate company, owned by its member banks who will also have a minority stake in Visa Inc.Bruno, Joel Bel. [http://biz.yahoo.com/ap/070622/visa_ipo.html "Visa Reveals Plan to Restructure for IPO"], Associated Press, June 22, 2007. In total, more than 35 investment banks participated in the deal in several capacities, most notably as underwriters. On October 3, 2007, Visa completed its corporate restructuring with the formation of Visa Inc. The new company was the first step towards Visa's IPO.[http://www.corporate.visa.com/md/nr/press737.jsp?src=home "Visa, Inc. Complete Global Restructuring"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071213065416/http://www.corporate.visa.com/md/nr/press737.jsp?src=home |date=December 13, 2007 }}, ''Visa, Inc. Press Release'', October 3, 2007. The second step came on November 9, 2007, when the new Visa Inc. submitted its $10 billion IPO filing with the [[United States Securities and Exchange Commission|U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC).[https://www.reuters.com/article/ousivMolt/idUSN0938404720071109?pageNumber=1 "Visa files for $10 billion IPO"], Reuters, November 9, 2007. On February 25, 2008, Visa announced it would go ahead with an IPO of half its shares.[http://www.economist.com/displayStory.cfm?story_id=10753463&fsrc=RSS "Visa plans a $19 billion initial public offering"]. ''The Economist''. February 25, 2008. The IPO took place on March 18, 2008. Visa sold 406 million shares at US$44 per share ($2 above the high end of the expected $37–42 pricing range), raising US$17.9 billion in what was then the largest initial public offering in U.S. history.Benner, Katie. [https://money.cnn.com/2008/03/18/news/companies/benner_visa_ipo.fortune/index.htm?section=money_latest "Visa's $15 billion IPO: Feast or famine?"], ''Fortune'' via ''CNNMoney'', March 18, 2008. On March 20, 2008, the IPO underwriters (including JP Morgan, Goldman Sachs & Co., Bank of America Securities LLC, Citi, HSBC, Merrill Lynch & Co., UBS Investment Bank and Wachovia Securities) exercised their overallotment option, purchasing an additional 40.6 million shares, bringing Visa's total IPO share count to 446.6 million, and bringing the total proceeds to US$19.1 billion.[http://investor.visa.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=215693&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1120608&highlight= "Visa Inc. Announces Exercise of Over-Allotment Option"], ''Visa Inc. Press Release'', March 20, 2008. {{webarchive|url=https://archive.today/20120721151612/http://investor.visa.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=215693&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1120608&highlight= |date=July 21, 2012 }} Visa now trades under the [[ticker symbol]] "V" on the [[New York Stock Exchange]].[http://www.thestreet.com/s/visa-ipo-seeks-mastercard-riches/newsanalysis/serious-tools-serious-investors/10401747.html?puc=_htmlbtb "Visa IPO Seeks MasterCard Riches"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080207063749/http://www.thestreet.com/s/visa-ipo-seeks-mastercard-riches/newsanalysis/serious-tools-serious-investors/10401747.html?puc=_htmlbtb |date=February 7, 2008 }}, ''TheStreet.com'', February 2, 2008. ===Visa Europe=== Visa Europe Ltd. was a membership association and cooperative of over 3,700 European banks and other [[payment service provider]]s{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/visaeurope-sale-idUSL3N0CB1K620130319 |title=Visa Europe members exploring sale to Visa – WSJ |work=Reuters |date=March 19, 2013 |access-date=July 18, 2013}} that operated Visa branded products and services within Europe. Visa Europe was a company entirely separate from Visa Inc. having gained independence of Visa International Service Association in October 2007 when Visa Inc. became a [[publicly traded company]] on the [[New York Stock Exchange]].{{cite web|url=http://www.visaeurope.com/en/newsroom/faqs.aspx |title=FAQs |publisher=Visaeurope.com |access-date=July 18, 2013}} Visa Inc. announced the plan to acquire Visa Europe on November 2, 2015, creating a single global company.{{cite press release |url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20151102005571/en/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171106151759/http://pressreleases.visa.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=215693&p=irol-newsarticlePR&ID=2104987 |archive-date=6 November 2017 |url-status=live |title=Visa Inc. to Acquire Visa Europe |date=2 November 2015 |access-date=29 October 2022}}{{cbignore}} On April 21, 2016, the agreement was amended in response to the feedback of [[European Commission]].{{cite web|url=http://investor.visa.com/news/news-details/2016/Visa-Inc-Reaches-Preliminary-Agreement-to-Amend-Transaction-With-Visa-Europe/default.aspx|title=Visa Inc. Reaches Preliminary Agreement to Amend Transaction With Visa Europe|date=21 April 2016|access-date=25 April 2016|publisher=Visa Inc.}} The acquisition of Visa Europe was completed on June 21, 2016.{{Cite press release |url=https://investor.visa.com/news/news-details/2016/Visa-Inc-Completes-Acquisition-of-Visa-Europe/default.aspx8 |title=Visa Inc. Completes Acquisition of Visa Europe |date=21 June 2016 |website=Visa Investor Relations |access-date=2022-10-29}} === Failed acquisition of Plaid === On January 13, 2020, [[Plaid (company)|Plaid]] announced that it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by Visa for $5.3 billion.{{Cite web|title=Visa is acquiring Plaid for $5.3 billion, 2x its final private valuation|url=http://social.techcrunch.com/2020/01/13/visa-is-acquiring-plaid-for-5-3-billion-2x-its-final-private-valuation/|access-date=2020-01-13|website=TechCrunch|date=January 13, 2020 |language=en-US}}{{Cite web|title=With Plaid Acquisition, Visa Makes A Big Play for the 'Plumbing' That Connects the Fintech World|url=https://fortune.com/2020/01/14/visa-plaid-acquisition-fintech/|access-date=2020-01-28|website=Fortune|language=en}} The deal was double the company's most recent Series C round valuation of $2.65 billion,{{Cite web|title=What Plaid's $5.3 Billion Acquisition Means For The Future Of Fintech And Open Banking|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/plaids-5-3-billion-acquisition-140706256.html|access-date=2020-03-22|website=finance.yahoo.com|language=en-US}} and was expected to close in the next 3–6 months, subject to regulatory review and closing conditions. According to the deal, Visa would pay $4.9 billion in cash and approximately $400 million of retention equity and deferred equity,{{Cite news|last=Demos|first=Telis|date=2020-01-14|title=Visa's Bet on Plaid Is Costly but Necessary|language=en-US|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/visas-bet-on-plaid-is-costly-but-necessary-11579001400|access-date=2020-03-22|issn=0099-9660}} according to a presentation deck prepared by Visa.{{Cite web|title=Visa to acquire crypto-serving fintech unicorn Plaid for $5.3B|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/visa-acquire-crypto-serving-fintech-064015237.html|access-date=2020-03-22|website=finance.yahoo.com|language=en-US}} On November 5, 2020, the [[United States Department of Justice]] filed a lawsuit seeking to block the acquisition, arguing that Visa is a [[Monopoly|monopolist]] trying to eliminate a competitive threat by purchasing Plaid. Visa said it disagrees with the lawsuit and "intends to defend the transaction vigorously."{{Cite news|last=Noonan|first=Laura|date=2020-11-05|title=US justice department sues to block Visa's $5.3bn Plaid takeover|work=Financial Times|url=https://www.ft.com/content/03bbf74e-697b-4989-8942-98e6a327e87d |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221210/https://www.ft.com/content/03bbf74e-697b-4989-8942-98e6a327e87d |archive-date=December 10, 2022 |url-access=subscription|access-date=2020-11-06}}{{Cite news|date=2020-11-05|title=U.S. sues Visa to block its acquisition of Plaid|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-visa-lawsuit-plaid-idUSKBN27L26S|access-date=2020-11-07}} ===Digital currencies=== On February 3, 2021, Visa announced a partnership with First Boulevard, a [[neobank]] promoting cryptocurrency, which has been touted as a means of building generational wealth for Black Americans.{{cite web |last1=Ellis |first1=Nicquel Terry |title=Cryptocurrency has been touted as the key to building Black wealth. But critics are skeptical |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/20/us/cryptocurrency-black-investors-reaj/index.html |website=[[CNN]] |access-date=29 October 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220824065758/https://www.cnn.com/2022/08/20/us/cryptocurrency-black-investors-reaj/index.html |archive-date=24 August 2022 |date=20 August 2022 |url-status=live}} The partnership would allow their users to buy, sell, hold, and trade digital assets through [[Anchorage Digital]].{{cite news |url=https://www.pymnts.com/cryptocurrency/2021/visa-crypto-api-makes-cryptocurrency-economic-empowerment-tool/ |title=Visa: Crypto API Program Makes Crypto An Economic Empowerment Tool |work=PYMNTS |date=2021-02-03 |accessdate=2021-02-04 }}{{cite news |url=https://usa.visa.com/about-visa/newsroom/press-releases.releaseId.17721.html |title=Visa Expands Digital Currency Roadmap with First Boulevard |work=Visa |date= 2021-02-03 |accessdate=2021-02-04 }} On March 29, 2021, Visa announced the acceptance of stable coin [[USD Coin|USDC]] to settle transactions on its network.{{Cite web|title=Visa Moves to Allow Payment Settlements Using Cryptocurrency|url=https://gadgets.ndtv.com/internet/news/cryptocurrency-visa-payment-usdc-usd-coin-settlement-crypto-com-2401953|access-date=2021-03-30|website=NDTV Gadgets 360|language=en}} On December 19, 2022, Visa shared plans for auto-payments on StarkNet, a Layer 2 scaling solution for [[Ethereum]].[https://usa.visa.com/solutions/crypto/auto-payments-for-self-custodial-wallets.html Visa Crypto Thought Leadership – Auto Payments | Visa] Visa’s proposed solution would enable people to pay recurring bills while maintaining custody of their assets, a core tenet of [[Decentralized finance|DeFi]].[https://thedefiant.io/visa-autopayments-self-custody Visa Unveils Plans For Auto-Payments From Self-Custodied Wallets - The Defiant] ===Visa Foundation=== Registered in the United States as a [[501(c)(3) organization|501(c)(3) entity]], the Visa Foundation was created with the mission of supporting inclusive economies. In particular, economies in which individuals, businesses and communities can thrive with the support of grants and investments. Supporting resiliency, as well as the growth, of micro and small businesses that benefit women is a priority of the Visa Foundation. Furthermore, the Foundation prioritizes providing support to the community from a broad standpoint, as well as responding to disasters during crisis.{{Cite web|url=https://usa.visa.com/about-visa/newsroom/press-releases.releaseId.11016.html|title = Visa Launches Foundation with Inaugural Grant to Women's World Banking}} ===Other initiatives=== In December 2020, Visa Announced the launch of a new [[Startup accelerator|accelerator program]] across [[Asia-Pacific|Asia Pacific]] to further develop the region's [[financial technology]] ecosystem.{{Cite web|title=Visa has launched an Accelerator Program for Fintech startups across Asia Pacific.|url=https://beamstart.com/content/128503/visa-fintech-accelerator-program-launch|access-date=2020-12-18|website=Startup News, Networking, and Resources Hub {{!}} BEAMSTART|language=en}} The accelerator program aims to find and partner with [[Startup company|startup companies]] providing financial and payments technologies that could potentially leverage on Visa's network of bank and merchant partners in the region.{{Cite web|title=Accelerator|url=https://www.visa.com.sg/visa-everywhere/innovation/apaccelerator.html|access-date=2020-12-18|website=www.visa.com.sg|language=en}} == Finance == For the fiscal year 2022, Visa reported earnings of US$14.96 billion, with an annual revenue of US$29.31 billion, an increase of 21.6% over the previous fiscal cycle. As of 2022, the company ranked 147th on the [[Fortune 500|''Fortune'' 500]] list of the largest United States corporations by revenue.{{Cite web|url=https://fortune.com/company/visa/fortune500/|title=Fortune 500 Companies 2022: Visa|website=Fortune|language=en-US|access-date=2022-11-16}} Visa's shares traded at over $143 per share, and its market capitalization was valued at over US$280.2 billion in September 2018. {| class="wikitable float-left" style="text-align: right;" !Year !Revenue
in million US$ !Net income
in million US$ !Employees |- |2005{{Cite web|url=https://www.annualreports.com/HostedData/AnnualReportArchive/v/NYSE_V_2008.pdf|title=2008 Annual Report}} |2,665 |360 | |- |2006 |2,948 |455 | |- |2007 |3,590 |−1,076 |5,479 |- |2008 |6,263 |804 |5,765 |- |2009{{Cite web|url=https://www.annualreports.com/HostedData/AnnualReportArchive/v/NYSE_V_2009.pdf|title=2009 Annual Report}} |6,911 |2,353 |5,700 |- |2010{{Cite web|url=https://www.annualreports.com/HostedData/AnnualReportArchive/v/NYSE_V_2010.pdf|title=2010 Annual Report}} |8,065 |2,966 |6,800 |- |2011{{Cite web|url=https://www.annualreports.com/HostedData/AnnualReportArchive/v/NYSE_V_2011.pdf|title=2011 Annual Report}} |9,188 |3,650 |7,500 |- |2012{{Cite web|url=https://www.annualreports.com/HostedData/AnnualReportArchive/v/NYSE_V_2012.pdf|title=2012 Annual Report}} |10,421 |2,144 |8,500 |- |2013{{Cite web|url=https://www.annualreports.com/HostedData/AnnualReportArchive/v/NYSE_V_2013.pdf|title=2013 Annual Report}} |11,778 |4,980 |9,600 |- |2014{{Cite web|url=https://www.annualreports.com/HostedData/AnnualReportArchive/v/NYSE_V_2014.pdf|title=2014 Annual Report}} |12,702 |5,438 |9,500 |- |2015{{Cite web|url=https://www.annualreports.com/HostedData/AnnualReportArchive/v/NYSE_V_2015.pdf|title=2015 Annual Report}} |13,880 |6,328 |11,300 |- |2016{{Cite web|url=https://www.annualreports.com/HostedData/AnnualReportArchive/v/NYSE_V_2016.pdf|title=2016 Annual Report}} |15,082 |5,991 |11,300 |- |2017{{Cite news|url=https://www.fool.com/investing/2018/01/18/why-2017-was-a-year-to-remember-for-visa-inc.aspx|title=Why 2017 was a Year to Remember for Visa Inc. -- The Motley Fool|last=Volkman|first=Eric|date=2018-01-18|work=The Motley Fool|access-date=2018-11-11|language=en}} |18,358 |6,699 |12,400 |- |2018{{Cite web|url=https://s1.q4cdn.com/050606653/files/doc_financials/2018/q4/Visa-Inc.-Q4-2018-Financial-Results.pdf|title=2018 Q4 Revenue and Earnings}} |20,609 |10,301 |15,000 |- |2019{{Cite web|title=Visa, Inc - AnnualReports.com|url=https://www.annualreports.com/Company/visa-inc|access-date=2020-12-23|website=www.annualreports.com}} |22,977 |12,080 |19,500 |- |2020 |21,846 |10,866 |20,500 |- |2021{{Cite web |title=Visa Inc. Reports Fiscal Fourth Quarter and Full-Year 2021 Results |url=https://s1.q4cdn.com/050606653/files/doc_financials/2021/q4/Visa-Inc.-Fourth-Quarter-and-Full-Year-2021-Financial-Results.pdf}} |24,105 |12,311 |21,500 |- |2022 |29,310 |14,957 |26,500 |} ==Criticism and controversy== ===WikiLeaks=== Visa Europe began suspending payments to [[WikiLeaks]] on December 7, 2010.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-11938320 ''BBC News'']. Retrieved December 8, 2010. The company said it was awaiting an investigation into 'the nature of its business and whether it contravenes Visa operating rules' – though it did not go into details.[http://www.salon.com/news/politics/war_room/2011/01/26/wikileaks_not_breaking_law/index.html No proof WikiLeaks breaking law, inquiry finds], [[Associated Press]] (January 26, 2011) {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110129033837/http://www.salon.com/news/politics/war_room/2011/01/26/wikileaks_not_breaking_law/index.html |date=January 29, 2011 }} In return DataCell, the [[information technology|IT]] company that enables WikiLeaks to accept credit and debit card donations, announced that it would take legal action against Visa Europe.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-11945875 |title=Wikileaks' IT firm says it will sue Visa and Mastercard |agency=BBC News |date = December 8, 2010| access-date = December 8, 2010}} On December 8, the group [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] performed a [[DDoS]] attack on visa.com,{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/08/wikileaks-visa-mastercard-operation-payback |title=WikiLeaks supporters disrupt Visa and MasterCard sites in 'Operation Payback' |date=8 December 2010 |work=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=5 January 2019}} bringing the site down.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/blog/2010/dec/08/wikileaks-us-embassy-cables-live-updates|title=WikiLeaks: the day cyber warfare broke out – as it happened|first1=Richard|last1=Adams|first2=Matthew|last2=Weaver|date=December 8, 2010|newspaper=The Guardian}} Although the Norway-based financial services company Teller AS, which Visa ordered to look into WikiLeaks and its fundraising body, the Sunshine Press, found no proof of any wrongdoing, ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'' reported in January 2011 that Visa Europe "would continue blocking donations to the secret-spilling site until it completes its own investigation". The [[United Nations]] [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]] [[Navi Pillay]] stated that Visa may be "violating WikiLeaks' right to freedom of expression" by withdrawing their services.[http://www.unmultimedia.org/tv/unifeed/d/16541.html UNifeed Geneva/Pillay] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324214612/http://www.unmultimedia.org/tv/unifeed/d/16541.html |date=March 24, 2012 }}, UN Web site. Retrieved on December 15, 2010. In July 2012, the Reykjavík District Court decided that [[Valitor]] (the Icelandic partner of Visa and MasterCard) was violating the law when it prevented donations to the site by credit card. It was ruled that the donations be allowed to return to the site within 14 days or they would be fined in the amount of US$6,000 per day.{{cite magazine|last=Zetter |first=Kim |url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/07/wikileaks-visa-blockade/ |title=WikiLeaks Wins Icelandic Court Battle Against Visa for Blocking Donations | Threat Level |magazine=Wired |date= July 12, 2012|access-date=March 26, 2013}} ===Litigation and regulatory actions=== {{Further|Fixed Acquirer Network Fee}} ====Anti-competitive conduct in Australia==== In 2015, the Australian Federal Court ordered Visa to pay a pecuniary penalty of $20 million (including legal fees) for engaging in anti-competitive conduct against dynamic currency conversion operators, in proceedings brought by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.{{Cite web|url=https://www.accc.gov.au/media-release/visa-ordered-to-pay-18-million-penalty-for-anti-competitive-conduct-following-accc-action|title=Visa ordered to pay $18 million penalty for anti-competitive conduct following ACCC action|first=Australian Competition and Consumer|last=Commission|date=September 4, 2015|website=Australian Competition and Consumer Commission}} ====Antitrust lawsuit by ATM operators==== In 2011, MasterCard and Visa were sued in a class action by ATM operators claiming the credit card networks' rules effectively fix ATM access fees.{{cite web|title=Complaint, U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission v. Home Depot USA Inc.|url=https://www.pacermonitor.com/view/PMOABZY/US_Equal_Employment_Opportunity_v_Home_Depot_USA_Inc__mddce-12-01952__0001.0.pdf|website=PacerMonitor|publisher=PacerMonitor|access-date=16 June 2016}} The suit claimed that this is a restraint on trade in violation of US federal law. The lawsuit was filed by the National ATM Council and independent operators of automated teller machines. More specifically, it is alleged that MasterCard's and Visa's network rules prohibit ATM operators from offering lower prices for transactions over PIN-debit networks that are not affiliated with Visa or MasterCard. The suit says that this price-fixing artificially raises the price that consumers pay using ATMs, limits the revenue that ATM-operators earn, and violates the [[Sherman Act]]'s prohibition against unreasonable restraints of trade. Johnathan Rubin, an attorney for the plaintiffs said, "Visa and MasterCard are the ringleaders, organizers, and enforcers of a conspiracy among U.S. banks to fix the price of ATM access fees in order to keep the competition at bay."{{cite press release |title=ATM Operators File Antitrust Lawsuit Against Visa and MasterCard |date=October 12, 2011 |publisher=PR Newswire|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/atm-operators-file-antitrust-lawsuit-against-visa-and-mastercard-131605078.html|access-date=15 September 2019}} In 2017, a US district court denied the ATM operators' request to stop Visa from enforcing the ATM fees.{{cite web |title=National Atm Council, Inc. v. Visa Inc., Civil Action No. 2011-1803 (D.D.C. 2017)|date=22 May 2017 |publisher=Court Listener|url=https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/4393490/national-atm-council-inc-v-visa-inc/|access-date=12 Jul 2020}} ====Debit card swipe fees==== In 1996, a class of U.S. merchants, including [[Walmart]], brought an [[antitrust]] lawsuit against Visa and [[MasterCard]] over their "Honor All Cards" policy, which forced merchants who accepted Visa and MasterCard branded credit cards to also accept their respective debit cards (such as the "Visa Check Card"). Over 4 million class members were represented by the plaintiffs. According to a website associated with the suit,[http://www.inrevisacheck-mastermoneyantitrustlitigation.com/ "Visa Check/MasterMoney Antitrust Litigation"], Web Site. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060428071336/http://www.inrevisacheck-mastermoneyantitrustlitigation.com/ |date=April 28, 2006 }} Visa and [[MasterCard]] settled the plaintiffs' claims in 2003 for a total of $3.05 billion. Visa's share of this settlement is reported to have been the larger. ====U.S. Justice Department actions==== In 1998, the Department of Justice sued Visa over rules prohibiting its issuing banks from doing business with [[American Express]] and [[Discover Card|Discover]]. The Department of Justice won its case at trial in 2001 and the verdict was upheld on appeal. American Express and Discover filed suit as well.{{cite news |title=Credit Card Market Is Unfair, Noncompetitive |author=Mallory Duncan |newspaper=Roll Call |date=July 10, 2012}} In October 2010, Visa and MasterCard reached a settlement with the [[U.S. Justice Department]] in another antitrust case. The companies agreed to allow merchants displaying their logos to decline certain types of cards (because [[interchange fee]]s differ), or to offer consumers discounts for using cheaper cards.{{Cite news|url=http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2010/10/04/pm-visa-mastercard-settlement-means-more-flexibility-for-retailers/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727192417/http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2010/10/04/pm-visa-mastercard-settlement-means-more-flexibility-for-retailers/|url-status=dead|title=Visa, Mastercard settlement means more flexibility for merchants|archive-date=July 27, 2011|work=Marketplace|publisher=American Public Radio}} ====Antitrust issues in Europe==== In 2002, the [[European Commission]] exempted Visa's multilateral interchange fees from Article 81 of the EC Treaty that prohibits anti-competitive arrangements.{{cite press release |title=Commission exempts multilateral interchange fees for cross-border Visa card payments |publisher=[[European Commission]] |date=July 24, 2002 |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/02/1138&format=HTML&aged=1&language=EN&guiLanguage=en |access-date=February 18, 2011}} However, this exemption expired on December 31, 2007. In the United Kingdom, Mastercard has reduced its interchange fees while it is under investigation by the Office of Fair Trading. In January 2007, the European Commission issued the results of a two-year inquiry into the retail banking sector. The report focuses on payment cards and interchange fees. Upon publishing the report, Commissioner [[Neelie Kroes]] said the "present level of interchange fees in many of the schemes we have examined does not seem justified." The report called for further study of the issue.{{cite press release |title=Competition: Commission sector inquiry finds major competition barriers in retail banking |publisher=[[European Commission]] |date=January 31, 2007 |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/07/114&format=HTML&aged=1&language=EN&guiLanguage=en |access-date=February 18, 2011}} On March 26, 2008, the European Commission opened an investigation into Visa's multilateral interchange fees for cross-border transactions within the EEA as well as into the "Honor All Cards" rule (under which merchants are required to accept all valid Visa-branded cards).{{cite press release |title=Antitrust: Commission initiates formal proceedings against Visa Europe Limited |publisher=[[European Commission]] |date=March 26, 2008 |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO/08/170&format=HTML&aged=0&language=EN&guiLanguage=en |access-date=February 18, 2011}}{{update inline|date=February 2015}} The antitrust authorities of EU member states (other than the United Kingdom) also investigated Mastercard's and Visa's interchange fees. For example, on January 4, 2007, the Polish Office of Competition and Consumer Protection fined twenty banks a total of PLN 164 million (about $56 million) for jointly setting Mastercard's and Visa's interchange fees.{{cite web|url=http://www.uokik.gov.pl/en/press_office/press_releases/art72.html|title=UOKiK – Home|last=UOKIK|website=www.uokik.gov.pl}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gvh.hu/gvh/alpha?do=2&st=2&pg=154&m129_doc=4413|title=Sector inquiry in the banking sector|date=February 8, 2007|access-date=April 30, 2013|archive-date=February 28, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228151448/http://www.gvh.hu/gvh/alpha?do=2&st=2&pg=154&m129_doc=4413|url-status=dead}} In December 2010, Visa reached a settlement with the [[European Union]] in yet another antitrust case, promising to reduce debit card payments to 0.2 percent of a purchase.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-eu-payments-cards-idUSKBN0JV2SV20141218|title=EU agrees deal to cap bank card payment fees|author1=Jan Strupczewski |author2=Foo Yun Chee |via=www.reuters.com|newspaper=Reuters|date=December 17, 2014}} A senior official from the [[European Central Bank]] called for a break-up of the Visa/Mastercard [[duopoly]] by creation of a new European debit card for use in the [[Single Euro Payments Area]] (SEPA).{{cite speech|url=https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/key/date/2010/html/sp101125_1.en.html|date=25 November 2010|title=SEPA: a busy year is coming to its end and another exciting year lies ahead}} After Visa's blocking of payments to [[WikiLeaks]], members of the European Parliament expressed concern that payments from European citizens to a European corporation could apparently be blocked by the US, and called for a further reduction in the dominance of Visa and Mastercard in the European payment system.{{cite web|url=http://www.trouw.nl/nieuws/media-technologie/article3332240.ece/Zorgen_over_dominantie_Visa_en_Mastercard_in_Europa.html/|title=Trouw.nl}} ====Payment Card Interchange Fee and Merchant Discount Antitrust Litigation==== {{Main | Payment Card Interchange Fee and Merchant Discount Antitrust Litigation}} On November 27, 2012, a federal judge entered an order granting preliminary approval to a proposed settlement to a class-action lawsuit{{cite web|url=https://www.paymentcardsettlement.com/Content/Documents/signed%20prelim%20approval%20order.pdf|date=November 27, 2012 |title=Class Settlement Preliminary Approval Order pg.11|work=[[United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York|U.S. District Court]]|access-date=July 9, 2019}} filed in 2005 by merchants and trade associations against Mastercard and Visa. The suit was filed due to alleged price-fixing practices employed by Mastercard and Visa. About one-quarter of the named class plaintiffs have decided to opt "out of the settlement". Opponents object to provisions that would bar future lawsuits and even prevent merchants from opting out of significant portions of the proposed settlement.{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/businessmain/judge-approves-credit-card-swipe-fee-settlement-2D11741836|last=Longstreth |first=Andrew|date=December 13, 2013|title=Judge approves credit card swipe fee settlement|work=[[NBC News]]|access-date=July 9, 2019}} Plaintiffs allege that Visa and [[Mastercard]] fixed [[interchange fees]], also known as swipe fees, that are charged to merchants for the privilege of accepting payment cards. In their complaint, the plaintiffs also alleged that the defendants unfairly interfere with merchants from encouraging customers to use less expensive forms of payment such as lower-cost cards, cash, and checks. A settlement of [[United States dollar|US$]]6.24 billion has been reached and a court is scheduled to approve or deny the agreement on November 7, 2019.{{cite web|url=https://seekingalpha.com/news/3436264-visa-mastercard-6_24b-settlement-gets-preliminary-okay-court|date=February 22, 2019|title=Visa, Mastercard $6.24B settlement gets preliminary okay from court|work=[[Seeking Alpha]]|access-date=July 9, 2019}} ===High swipe fees in Poland=== Very high interchange fee for Visa (1.5–1.6% from every transaction's final price, which also includes [[VAT]]) in Poland started discussion about legality and need for government regulations of interchange fees to avoid high costs for business (which also block electronic payment market and acceptability of cards).{{cite web|url=http://www.ekonomia24.pl/artykul/960467.html?print=tak&p=0 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130416104823/http://www.ekonomia24.pl/artykul/960467.html?print=tak&p=0 |url-status=dead |archive-date=April 16, 2013 |title=Rynek kart czekają zmiany (wersja do druku) |language=pl |publisher=Ekonomia24.pl |access-date=March 26, 2013}} This situation also led to the birth of new methods of payment in the year 2013, which avoid the need for go-between (middleman) companies like Visa or Mastercard, for example mobile application issued by major banks,{{cite web|url=http://banki.wp.pl/kat,6599,title,IKO-rewolucyjny-system-platnosci-mobilnej-od-PKO-BP,wid,15393602,wiadomosc.html |title=IKO: rewolucyjny system płatności mobilnej od PKO BP – Banki – WP.PL |publisher=Banki |access-date=March 26, 2013}} and system by big chain of discount shops,{{cite news|url=http://tech.wp.pl/kat,130058,title,Platnosci-mobilne-w-Biedronce,wid,15230102,wiadomosc.html |title=Płatności mobilne w Biedronce – Tech – WP.PL |newspaper=Tech |access-date=March 26, 2013}} or older public transport tickets buying systems.{{cite web |url=http://www.skycash.com/en/about-skycash/in-phone-ticket/in-phone-ticket.html |title=Mobile Payments – Bilet w komórce |publisher=Skycash.com |access-date=March 26, 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121117012646/http://skycash.com/en/about-skycash/in-phone-ticket/in-phone-ticket.html |archive-date=November 17, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} ===Confrontation with Walmart over high fees=== In June 2016, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that [[Walmart Canada|Walmart]] threatened to stop accepting Visa cards in Canada. Visa objected saying that consumers should not be dragged into a dispute between the companies.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/visa-defends-fees-in-wal-mart-canada-dispute-1466049661|title=Visa Defends Fees in Wal-Mart Canada Dispute|first=Robin|last=Sidel|date=June 16, 2016|newspaper=Wall Street Journal}} In January 2017, Walmart Canada and Visa reached a deal to allow the continued acceptance of Visa.{{cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/business/visa-walmart-1.3923039|title=Walmart strikes deal with Visa to settle credit card fee dispute|first=Pete|last=Evans|date=5 January 2017|newspaper=CBC}} ===Dispute with Kroger over high credit card fees=== In March 2019, U.S. retailer [[Kroger]] announced that its 250-strong [[Smith's Food and Drug|Smith's]] chain would stop accepting Visa credit cards as of April 3, 2019, due to the cards’ high ‘swipe’ fees. Kroger's California-based [[Food 4 Less|Foods Co]] stores stopped accepting Visa cards in August 2018. Mike Schlotman, Kroger's executive vice president/chief financial officer, said Visa had been “misusing its position and charging retailers excessive fees for a long time.” In response, Visa issued a statement saying it was “unfair and disappointing that Kroger is putting shoppers in the middle of a business dispute.”{{cite web |last1=Morris |first1=Chris |title=Kroger Bans Visa Cards at 250 Additional Stores |url=http://fortune.com/2019/03/01/kroger-bans-visa-cards-at-250-additional-stores/ |website=Fortune |access-date=5 March 2019 |language=en}} As of October 31, 2019, Kroger has settled their dispute with Visa and is now accepting the payment method.{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/kroger-reverses-visa-credit-card-ban-2019-10|title=Kroger has reversed its ban on Visa credit cards after previously accusing the company of 'excessive fees' that 'drive up food prices'|last=Peterson|first=Hayley|website=Business Insider|access-date=2019-10-31|date=October 30, 2019}} === Antitrust investigation over debit card practices === In March 2021, [[United States Department of Justice|the United States Justice Department]] announced its investigation with Visa to discover if the company is engaging in anticompetitive practices in the debit card market. The main question at hand is whether or not Visa is limiting merchants' ability to route debit card transactions over card networks that are often less expensive, focusing more so on online debit card transactions. The probe highlights the role of network fees, which are invisible to consumers and place pressure on merchants, who mitigate the fees by raising prices of goods for customers. The probe was confirmed through a regulatory filing on March 19, 2021, stating they will be cooperating with the Justice Department. Visa's shares fell more than 6% following the announcement.{{Cite news|last=Kendall|first=AnnaMaria Andriotis and Brent|date=2021-03-19|title=WSJ News Exclusive {{!}} Visa Faces Antitrust Investigation Over Debit-Card Practices|language=en-US|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/justice-department-investigating-visa-over-debit-card-practices-11616164525|access-date=2021-03-20|issn=0099-9660}}{{Cite news|agency=Associated Press|title=Report: DOJ investigating Visa over debit card business|language=en-US|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/report-doj-investigating-visa-over-debit-card-business/2021/03/19/186c6bd2-88d6-11eb-be4a-24b89f616f2c_story.html|access-date=2021-03-20|issn=0190-8286}}{{dead link|date=June 2021|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}{{Cite news|last=Copeland|first=Brent Kendall and Rob|date=2020-10-21|title=Justice Department Hits Google With Antitrust Lawsuit|language=en-US|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/justice-department-to-file-long-awaited-antitrust-suit-against-google-11603195203|access-date=2021-03-20|issn=0099-9660}}{{Cite news|last=Torry|first=AnnaMaria Andriotis and Harriet|date=2020-06-21|title=The Credit-Card Fees Merchants Hate, Banks Love and Consumers Pay|language=en-US|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-credit-card-fees-merchants-hate-banks-love-and-consumers-pay-11592731800|access-date=2021-03-20|issn=0099-9660}} ==Corporate affairs== ===Headquarters=== In 2009, Visa moved its corporate headquarters back to San Francisco when it leased the top three floors of the [[595 Market Street]] office building, although most of its employees remained at its Foster City campus."[https://web.archive.org/web/20110716093535/http://www.smdailyjournal.com/article_preview.php?id=103518 Week in review]." ''[[San Mateo Daily Journal|The Daily Journal]]''. January 3, 2009. Retrieved on February 2, 2011. In 2012, Visa decided to consolidate its headquarters in Foster City where 3,100 of its 7,700 global workers are employed.{{cite news |last=Leuty |first=Ron |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/news/2012/09/13/visa-headquarters-foster-city.html?page=all |title=Visa moving headquarters from San Francisco to Foster City |work=San Francisco Business Times |date=September 13, 2012 |access-date=February 27, 2013 |quote=[Visa] said Thursday that it is closing its headquarters in San Francisco and moving about 100 employees back to its Foster City campus, effective October 1. [...] The bulk of the company's employees—3,100 of more than 7,700 worldwide... are in Foster City.}} Visa owns four buildings at the intersection of Metro Center Boulevard and Vintage Park Drive. As of October 1, 2012, Visa's headquarters are located in Foster City, California. Visa had been headquartered in San Francisco until 1985, when it moved to [[San Mateo, California|San Mateo]]."[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SJ&s_site=mercurynews&p_multi=SJ&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB71EB44CAF454E&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Visa finds a passport to the future San Mateo Company bets on 'SMART' cards that will exchange information, not just money]." ''[[San Jose Mercury News]]''. Monday August 7, 1995. 1F Business. Retrieved on February 2, 2011. "Visa's headquarters remained in San Francisco until 1985 when it relocated to San Mateo. Then, two years ago, it began consolidating scattered sites throughout San Mateo in nearby Foster City with [...]". Around 1993, Visa began consolidating various scattered offices in San Mateo to a location in Foster City. Visa became Foster City's largest employer. In December 2012, Visa Inc. confirmed that it will build a global information technology center off of the [[U.S. Route 183 in Texas|US 183]] Expressway in northwest [[Austin, Texas]].{{cite news|last=Ladendorf |first=Kirk |url=http://www.statesman.com/news/business/visa-confirms-plans-for-austin-offices/nTSm6/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121215010733/http://www.statesman.com/news/business/visa-confirms-plans-for-austin-offices/nTSm6/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=December 15, 2012 |title=Visa confirms plans for Austin offices |work=Austin American-Statesman |date=December 11, 2012 |access-date=February 27, 2013 }} By 2019, Visa leased space in four buildings near Austin and employed nearly 2,000 people.{{cite news|last=Wells|first=Arnold |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/news/2019/05/14/visa-grows-tech-center-in-north-austin.html |title=Visa grows tech center in North Austin|work=Austin Business Journal |date=14 May 2019 |access-date=15 September 2019 }} On November 6, 2019, Visa announced plans to move its headquarters back to San Francisco by 2024 upon completion of a new "13-story, 300,000-square-foot building".{{cite news |last1=Leuty |first1=Ron |title=Visa moving global HQ, up to 1,500 employees to Giants' Mission Rock |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/news/2019/11/06/visa-moving-global-hq-1-500-employees-to-giants.html |access-date=22 October 2020 |work=San Francisco Business Times |publisher=American City Business Journals |date=November 6, 2019}} ==Operations== Visa offers through its issuing members the following types of cards: * [[Debit card]]s (pay from a checking/savings account) * [[Credit card]]s (pay monthly payments with or without interest depending on a customer paying on time) * [[Stored-value card|Prepaid card]]s (pay from a cash account that has no check writing privileges) Visa operates the [[Plus (interbank network)|Plus]] [[automated teller machine]] network and the [[Interlink (interbank network)|Interlink]] [[EFTPOS]] [[Point of sale|point-of-sale]] network, which facilitate the "debit" protocol used with debit cards and prepaid cards. They also provide commercial payment solutions for small businesses, midsize and large corporations, and governments.[http://www.allbusiness.com/banking-finance/banking-lending-credit-services-cash/5589674-1.html "Synovus Selects Visa's Plus and Interlink as Primary Debit Network Providers"], AllBusiness, April 6, 2004. Retrieved July 2, 2010. Visa teamed with [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] in September 2014, to incorporate a new mobile wallet feature into Apple's new [[iPhone]] models, enabling users to more readily use their Visa, and other credit/debit cards.{{cite news|title=Apple teams with payment networks to turn iPhone into wallet|url=http://www.sandiegonews.net/index.php/sid/225274025|date=September 1, 2014|access-date=September 1, 2014|publisher=San Diego News. Net}} ===Operating regulations=== Visa has a set of rules that govern the participation of financial institutions in its payment system. [[Acquiring bank]]s are responsible for ensuring that their merchants comply with the rules. Rules address how a cardholder must be identified for [[security]], how transactions may be denied by the bank, and how banks may cooperate for [[fraud]] prevention, and how to keep that identification and fraud protection standard and non-discriminatory. Other rules govern what creates an enforceable proof of authorization by the cardholder.[http://www.orionps.com/pdfs/VISA%20rules%20for%20merchants.pdf "Visa Rules for Merchants"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110126034446/http://www.orionps.com/pdfs/VISA%20rules%20for%20merchants.pdf |date=January 26, 2011 }}, Orion Payment Systems, Retrieved July 2, 2010. The rules prohibit merchants from imposing a minimum or maximum purchase amount in order to accept a Visa card and from charging cardholders a fee for using a Visa card. In ten U.S. states, surcharges for the use of a credit card are forbidden by law ([[California]], [[Colorado]], [[Connecticut]], [[Florida]], [[Kansas]], [[Maine]], [[Massachusetts]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[Oklahoma]] and [[Texas]]) but a discount for cash is permitted under specific rules.{{cite web|url=http://usa.visa.com/personal/using_visa/no-surcharge.html|title=Visa USA Inc|access-date=June 27, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110121195418/http://usa.visa.com/personal/using_visa/no-surcharge.html|archive-date=January 21, 2011|url-status=dead}} Some countries have banned the no-surcharge rule, most notably in Australia[http://www.rba.gov.au/payments-system/surcharging/index.html "Reforms to Payment Card Surcharging."], Reserve Bank of Australia. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328023445/http://www.rba.gov.au/payments-system/surcharging/index.html |date=March 28, 2014 }} retailers may apply surcharges to any credit-card transaction, Visa or otherwise. In the UK the law was changed in January 2018 to prevent retailers from adding a surcharge to a transaction as per '[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2012/3110/contents/made The Consumer Rights (Payment Surcharges) Regulations 2012]'. Visa permits merchants to ask for photo ID, although the merchant rule book states that this practice is discouraged. As long as the Visa card is signed, a merchant may not deny a transaction because a cardholder refuses to show a photo ID. The [[Dodd–Frank Act]] allows U.S. merchants to set a minimum purchase amount on credit card transactions, not to exceed $10.{{cite web|url=http://usa.visa.com/about_visa/ask_visa/index.html|title=Ask Visa |publisher=usa.visa.com|access-date=September 14, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041020012114/http://www.usa.visa.com/about_visa/ask_visa/index.html|archive-date=October 20, 2004|url-status=dead}}{{cite web|url=http://www.paymentssource.com/news/merchants-debit-transactions-cheaper-3003058-1.html|title=Emboldened, Merchants Expected To Push Cheaper Payments|PaymentsSource|publisher=paymentssource.com|access-date=September 14, 2014|date=August 25, 2010}} Recent complications include the addition of exceptions for non-signed purchases by telephone or on the Internet and an additional security system called "[[Verified by Visa]]" for purchases on the Internet. In September 2014, Visa Inc, launched a new service to replace account information on plastic cards with "token" – a digital account number.[https://www.reuters.com/news/picture/visa-launches-new-service-to-secure-onli-idUSKBN0H425920140909 "Visa launches new service to secure online payments"], Reuters, Retrieved September 10, 2014. == Products == ===Visa Credit Cards=== Depending on the geographical location, Visa card issuer issue the following tiers of cards, from the lowest to the highest:[https://www.visa.com.ph/pay-with-visa/find-a-card/credit-cards.html Visa Credit Card] * Traditional/Classic/Standard * Gold * Platinum * Signature (Worldwide except Canada)[https://www.visa.ca/content/dam/VCOM/regional/na/canada/Support/Documents/Visa%20Canada%20Interchange%20Rates%20(April%202022).pdf Visa Canada Interchange Reimbursement Fees] * Infinite * Infinite Privilege (Canada only)[https://www.visa.ca/en_CA/pay-with-visa/cards/credit-cards.html Visa Credit Card Canada] ===Visa Debit=== {{main|Visa Debit}} This is the standard Visa-branded [[debit card]]. === Visa Electron === {{main|Visa Electron}} A Visa-branded debit card issued worldwide since the 1990s. Its distinguishing feature is that it does not allow [[Card not present transaction|"card not present"]] transactions while its [[floor limit]] is set to zero, which triggers automatic authorisation of each transaction with the issuing bank and effectively makes it impossible for the user to [[overdraft|overdraw]] the account. The card has often been issued to younger customers or those who may pose a risk of overdrawing the account. Since mid-2000s, the card has mostly been replaced by Visa Debit. === Visa Cash === {{main|Visa Cash}} A Visa-branded [[stored-value card]]. ===Visa Contactless (formerly payWave){{anchor|payWave}}{{anchor|Visa Contactless}}=== [[File:EMVCoContactlessIndicator.svg|75px|right]] In September 2007, Visa introduced '''Visa payWave''', a [[contactless payment]] technology feature that allows cardholders to wave their card in front of contactless payment terminals without the need to physically swipe or insert the card into a point-of-sale device.{{cite news|url=http://www.smartcardalliance.org/articles/2007/09/20/new-visa-paywave-issuers-and-merchants-sign-up-for-faster-more-convenient-payments |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102074728/http://www.smartcardalliance.org/articles/2007/09/20/new-visa-paywave-issuers-and-merchants-sign-up-for-faster-more-convenient-payments |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 2, 2008 |title=New Visa payWave Issuers and Merchants Sign Up for Faster, More Convenient Payments }} This is similar to the Mastercard [[MasterCard#Mastercard Contactless|Contactless]] service and the [[American Express]] [[ExpressPay]], with both using [[radio-frequency identification|RFID]] technology. All three use the same symbol as shown on the right. In Europe, Visa has introduced the [[V Pay]] card, which is a [[smart card|chip]]-only and [[personal identification number|PIN]]-only debit card.{{cite news|url=http://www.vpay.com/banks.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070517173109/http://www.vpay.com/banks.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=May 17, 2007 |title=V PAY – your European debit card }} In Australia, take up has been the highest in the world, with more than 50% of in store Visa transactions now made via Visa payWave.{{cite news | url = http://www.bpaybanter.com.au/news-views/why-do-australians-lead-the-way-in-contactless-pay | title = Why do Australians lead the way in contactless payments? }} ===mVisa=== mVisa is a mobile payment app allowing payment via [[smartphones]] using [[QR code]]. This [[QR code payment]] method was first introduced in India in 2015. It was later expanded to a number of other countries, including in Africa and South East Asia.{{cite news |url=https://www.nfcworld.com/2017/02/28/350578/mastercard-visa-expand-availability-qr-payments/ |title=Mastercard and Visa expand availability of QR payments |date=February 28, 2017 |author=Sarah Clark}}{{cite news |url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/banking/finance/banking/icici-launches-mvisa-mobile-payment-service/articleshow/49274142.cms |title=ICICI launches 'mVisa' mobile payment service |date=October 8, 2015 |newspaper=The Economic Times}} ===Visa Checkout=== In 2013, Visa launched Visa Checkout, an online payment system that removes the need to share card details with retailers. The Visa Checkout service allows users to enter all their personal details and card information, then use a single username and password to make purchases from online retailers. The service works with Visa credit, debit, and prepaid cards. On November 27, 2013, V.me went live in the UK, France, Spain and Poland, with Nationwide Building Society being the first financial institution in Britain to support it,{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/internet/10477605/Visa-launch-V.me-digital-wallet-service.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220111/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/internet/10477605/Visa-launch-V.me-digital-wallet-service.html |archive-date=January 11, 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Matthew | last=Sparkes | title=Visa launch V.me digital wallet service | date=November 27, 2013}}{{cbignore}} although Nationwide subsequently withdrew this service in 2016. ==Trademark and design== ===Logo design=== The blue and gold in Visa's logo were chosen to represent the blue sky and gold-colored hills of [[California]], where the [[Bank of America]] was founded. In 2005, Visa changed its logo, removing the horizontal stripes in favor of a simple white background with the name Visa in blue with an orange flick on the 'V'.[http://corporate.visa.com/md/nb/hot/archives/brandevolution.jsp "Hot Topic: A Brand Evolution."], Visa Corporate Press Release, January 2007. The orange flick was removed in favor of the logo being a solid blue gradient in 2014. In 2015, the gold and blue stripes were restored as card branding on [[Visa Debit]] and [[Visa Electron]], although not as the company's logotype.{{cite web|title=20 Fun Facts You Never Knew About VISA|url=https://moneyinc.com/20-things-you-never-knew-about-visa/|publisher=MoneyInc|access-date=August 30, 2019|date=March 20, 2018}} ===Card design=== [[File:Visa holo.png|alt=The Dove hologram|thumb|The hologram]]In 1984, most Visa cards around the world began to feature a [[hologram]] of a [[dove]] on its face, generally under the last four digits of the Visa number. This was implemented as a security feature – true holograms would appear three-dimensional and the image would change as the card was turned. At the same time, the Visa logo, which had previously covered the whole card face, was reduced in size to a strip on the card's right incorporating the hologram. This allowed issuing banks to customize the appearance of the card. Similar changes were implemented with MasterCard cards. Today, cards may be co-branded with various merchants, airlines, etc., and marketed as "reward cards". On older Visa cards, holding the face of the card under an [[ultraviolet light]] will reveal the dove picture, dubbed the Ultra-Sensitive Dove,{{cite web|url=http://usa.visa.com/merchants/risk_management/payment_card_fraud.html|title=Payment Cards Fraud and Merchants|access-date=January 10, 2013|archive-date=January 15, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115132829/http://usa.visa.com/merchants/risk_management/payment_card_fraud.html|url-status=dead}} as an additional security test. (On newer Visa cards, the UV dove is replaced by a small V over the Visa logo.) Beginning in 2005, the Visa standard was changed to allow for the hologram to be placed on the back of the card, or to be replaced with a holographic magnetic stripe ("HoloMag").[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1052489/000110465905016332/a05-6155_2ex99d1.htm "HoloMag Introduced."], SEC.GOV Web Site. The HoloMag card was shown to occasionally cause interference with card readers, so Visa eventually withdrew designs of HoloMag cards and reverted to traditional magnetic strips.{{cite press release|url=http://www.ihma.org/files/uploadedfiles/109/ABNH%2031%20Mar%2006.pdf|date=March 31, 2006|title=American Bank Note Holographics Reports Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2005 Financial Results|url-status=dead|location=Robbinsville, New Jersey|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227092059/http://www.ihma.org/files/uploadedfiles/109/ABNH%2031%20Mar%2006.pdf|archive-date=February 27, 2008|quote=On March 14, 2006, Visa informed the Company ... that it is discontinuing the use of the current version of HoloMag based on what Visa describes as an infrequently occurring technical problem at the point of sale}} ==Signatures== Visa made a statement on January 12, 2018, that the signature requirement would become optional for all EMV contact or contactless chip-enabled merchants in North America starting in April 2018.
